greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 3; for n > 1, a(n) = 4*phi(n); given a rational number r = p/q, where q>0, (p,q)=1, define its height to be max{|p|,q}; then a(n) = number of rational numbers of height n.
comment: The old entry with this sequence number was a duplicate of A008831.
a(n) is also the number of integers prime to n in the interval [n+1, 5n-1]. [From _Washington Bomfim_, Oct 10 2009]
reference: M. N. Huxley, Area, Lattice Points and Exponential Sums, Oxford, 1996; p. 7.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: The three rational numbers of height 1 are 0, 1 and -1.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 02 2008
ext: A simpler alternative description added to the name field by _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 05 2017
